sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving coordination compounds.
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction: 

[Co(H2O)6]2+(aq) + 4Cl-(aq) → [CoCl4]2-(aq) + 6H2O(l) 

Given the following information:

• ΔH°f of [Co(H2O)6]2+ is 32.3 kJ/mol 

• ΔH°f of [CoCl4]2- is -341.8 kJ/mol 

• ΔH°f of H2O(l) is -285.8 kJ/mol 

• The ΔH°f of Cl- is taken as zero
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the reaction, we can use the formula:

ΔH° = Σ ΔH°f(products) - Σ ΔH°f(reactants)

For the products, we have:
1 mol of [CoCl4]2- and 6 mol of H2O(l)

For the reactants, we have:
1 mol of [Co(H2O)6]2+ and 4 mol of Cl-

Now, we can plug in the given values:

ΔH° = (1 mol × -341.8 kJ/mol + 6 mol × -285.8 kJ/mol) - (1 mol × 32.3 kJ/mol + 4 mol × 0 kJ/mol)

ΔH° = (-341.8 kJ + 6 × -285.8 kJ) - (32.3 kJ + 0 kJ)

ΔH° = (-341.8 kJ - 1714.8 kJ) - 32.3 kJ

ΔH° = -2056.6 kJ - 32.3 kJ

ΔH° = -2088.9 kJ

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction is -2088.9 kJ.
